fr:title.text: Affine scheme for natural numbers under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine scheme for natural numbers under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the distributive lattice \mathbb {N} given in Example , recall its prime spectral corresponds to prime power p^k, and 0. The corresponding prime filter F_{p^k} is the set of numbers not containing p^k as a factor, and F_0 is the set of positive numbers. This way, we have \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N},p^k} \cong \mathbb {N} /F_{p^k} \cong \{0 < \cdots < p^{k+2} < p^{k+1} < p^{k} < 1\} \cong \overline {\omega }^{\mathrm {op}}. consisting of the infinite descending sequence of powers of p, and \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N},0} \cong \mathbb {N} /F_{0} \cong 2. Notice that all the stalks are linear. Since linearity is a geometric condition, it follows that \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N}} is a linear distributive lattice over \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {N}. However, \mathbb {N} is by no means linear.
We will denote the objects of \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}} that lies in the image of \operatorname {Spec} as affine schemes.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes are determined by topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes are determined by topology

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Since \operatorname {Spec} : \mathbf {DL}^{\mathrm {op}} \to \mathbf {Spec} is an equivalence, affine schemes are determined by their underlying topological spaces.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of free distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of free distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the free distributive lattice 2[I] over a poset I, recall from Example \operatorname {Spec} 2[I] \cong \mathcal {U}(I). For any x\in \mathcal {U}(I), \mathcal {O}_{2[I],x} \cong 2[I]/x \cong 2[I-x]. Hence, the stalks of \operatorname {Spec} 2[I] are also free.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of bounded linear distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of bounded linear distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a bounded linear order L, recall from Example \operatorname {Spec} L \cong \mathcal {U}_+(L). For any upward closed subset x of L, we have \mathcal {O}_{L,x} \cong \operatorname {colim}_{p\in x}L/p \cong L/x, where L/x is simply the quotient of L by identifying x with 1 and the others remaining the same. In particular, each stalk is again a linear lattice.

fr:title.text: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the sub distributive lattice \mathbb {P} of \mathbb {N} described in Example , its prime spectrum can be identified as primes, plus 0. For any prime p the stalk now kills of all higher powers of p and is simply given by \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},p} \cong \{0 < p < 1\} \cong 2[x], and we also have \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},0} \cong 2. \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P}} is thus again a linear distributive lattice.
If we glue two affine schemes X,Y together along some standard opens U \subseteq X and V \subseteq Y with U \cong V, then the union X \cup Y is again affine.

fr:title.text: Prime spectrum of natural numbers under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime spectrum of natural numbers under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {N} denote the distributive lattice defined by n \le m \Leftrightarrow m \mid n. In this lattice, we have n \wedge m = \mathrm {lcm}(m,n), \quad n \vee m = \mathrm {gcd}(n,m). Also, the top element is 1, and the bottom element is 0. \mathbb {N} is in fact a Heyting algebra.
